linkTarget.anchoringText: The configuration of the obtained sand formations can be attributed to hose-like or lace-like sediments associated with river beds or coastlines (Fig. 1). Taking into account that the orientation of sand bodies basically coincides with the direction of the drift, an assumption was made about their alluvial delta genesis.

Electrometric models of beach facies and coastal regressive bars are similar (Fig. 2), they are right triangles and differ only in the width of the SP anomaly. The maximum deviations of the SP curve are characteristic for the upper part of the section.

Figure 3 shows well cumulative production and injection volumes on top of lithofacies distribution map, while Figure 4 represents overlay of maximum production and injection rates on top of lithofacies distribution map.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative production and injection volumes superimposed on lithofaces map

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative production and injection volumes superimposed on lithofaces map

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 shows well cumulative production and injection volumes on top of lithofacies distribution map, while Figure 4 represents overlay of maximum production and injection rates on top of lithofacies distribution map.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Maximum injection and production rates, superimposed onto lithofaces map

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum injection and production rates, superimposed onto lithofaces map

linkTarget.anchoringText: Areal perforation fraction distribution is shown on Fig.5. Low perforation fraction values for individual zones are explained by the presence of extensive water-oil zones, as well as the transfer of wells in the late development period (1992-2015) to partially washed zones with the perforation of the upper interval of the formation.

The results of PLTs carried out in 176 commingled wells were analysed and for 140 of them quantitative estimation of each horizon contribution was provided. Fig. 6 shows an example of such study and generalized results of the PLT. Analysis showed that there was no obvious maximum between each horizon contribution and it varies in each individual case depending on the geological structure and production history of the neighbouring area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: PLT results of comingled wells. a) – PLT example in well XC80, b) – analysed formation flow in comingled wells, c) – flowing fluid

formatted-caption.caption-text: PLT results of comingled wells. a) – PLT example in well XC80, b) – analysed formation flow in comingled wells, c) – flowing fluid

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: analysed formation flow in comingled wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: All wells in the field are covered by regular measurements of bottomhole pressure and flow rate. The data showed that the liquid production flow rates are in steady decline despite the relatively constant bottomhole pressure and reinjection of more than 100% of produced liquids. One of the reasons for that could be skin factor growth in production wells. Figure 7 shows bottomhole pressure and production rate dynamics for one well, where first peak in 2000 was due to re-perforation and second in 2015 due to near wellbore treatment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Well flowrate and bottomhole pressure dynamics in a well with declining production

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well flowrate and bottomhole pressure dynamics in a well with declining production

linkTarget.anchoringText: To verify this assumption about skin-factor growth, several specific targeted well tests have been performed, including pressure build-up curve and the pressure drawdown curve. Let us consider an example of such a well test. For the quantitative interpretation of bottomhole pressure measurements together with the well production rate changes, the method “Decline-Analyze” and algorithms of the software complexes “Topaze” and “Saphir” of Kappa Engineering company were used. An overview of the study is shown in Fig. 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Well test results in a declining production well (1 – test overview plot, 1- a – liquid production rate Q=f(t), 1-b – cumulative production ΣQ=f(t), 1-c – bottomhole pressure P=f(t), 2 - log-log plot ln ΔP=f(lnt), 3 – well location scheme)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test results in a declining production well (1 – test overview plot, 1- a – liquid production rate Q=f(t), 1-b – cumulative production ΣQ=f(t), 1-c – bottomhole pressure P=f(t), 2 - log-log plot ln ΔP=f(lnt), 3 – well location scheme)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analysis of well performance indicators, reservoir and bottomhole pressures, geological, geophysical and production data allowed to identify mutual influence between wells. Production well interference is rather low, because of low production rates. However, the production and injection wells interference is quite high. The interference pattern is shown in Fig. 9.
